elements.content: The reaction of aqueous [W3S7(C2O4)3]2- with Ln3+ and Th4+ in a 1:1 molar ratio leads to oxalate-bridged heteropolynuclear molecular complexes and coordination polymers. La3+ and Ce3+ give a layered structure with big (about 1.8 nm) honeycomb pores which are filled with water molecules and lanthanide ions, in {[Ln(H2O)6]3[W3S7(C2O4)3]4}Br·xH2O (Ia and Ib). The smaller Pr3+, Nd3+, Sm3+, Eu3+, and Gd3+ ions give discrete nanomolecules [(W3S7(C2O4)3Ln(H2O)5)2(μ-C2O4)] (with a separation of about 3.2 nm between the most distant parts of the molecule), which are further united into zigzag chains by specific S2···Br- contacts to achieve the overall stoichiometry K[(W3S7(C2O4)3Ln(H2O)5)2(μ-C2O4)]Br·xH2O (IIa−IId). Th4+ gives K2[(W3S7(C2O4)3)4Th2(OH)2(H2O)10]·14.33H2O (III) with a nanosized discrete anion (with a separation of about 2.7 nm between the most distant parts of the molecule), in which two thorium atoms are bound via two hydroxide groups into the Th2(OH)2 6+ unit, and each Th is further coordinated by five water molecules and two monodentate [W3S7(C2O4)]2- cluster ligands. All compounds were characterized by X-ray structure analysis and IR spectroscopy. Magnetic susceptibility measurements in the temperature range of 2−300 K show weak antiferromagnetic interactions between two lanthanides atoms for compounds IIa, IIb, and IId. The thermal decomposition of Ia, Ib, and IIb was studied by thermogravimetry.

elements.content: Coordination polymers based on mononuclear transition metal complexes with multifunctional bridging ligands are attracting much interest because of their potential applications in optoelectronic, magnetic, microporous, and biomimetic materials, as well as of their versatile intriguing architectures and topologies. The design of coordination polymers is highly influenced by diverse factors such as the coordination behavior of metal ions, the structural characteristics of polydentate organic ligands, the metal−ligand ratio, the possible counterion influence, and last but not the least, non-valence interactions. In some cases, a subtle alteration in any of these factors leads to completely different structures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Coordination polymers based on mononuclear transition metal complexes with multifunctional bridging ligands are attracting much interest because of their potential applications in optoelectronic, magnetic, microporous, and biomimetic materials, as well as of their versatile intriguing architectures and topologies. The design of coordination polymers is highly influenced by diverse factors such as the coordination behavior of metal ions, the structural characteristics of polydentate organic ligands, the metal-ligand ratio, the possible counterion influence, and last but not the least, non-valence interactions. In some cases, a subtle alteration in any of these factors leads to completely different structures.

elements.content: In particular, there has been a tremendous activity during the past decade in the area of molecular-based magnets. The oxalate ligand has emerged as a very appealing candidate because of its remarkable ability to mediate electronic effects between paramagnetic metal ions separated by more than 5 Å by adopting the bisbidentate bridging mode. Oxofilic Ln3+ ions lend themselves especially well to such studies.

elements.content: In this work we have used the recently prepared cluster oxalate complex [W3S7(ox)3]2- as a building block for the construction of nanosized complexes and coordination polymers with rare earths and Th4+ ions. The tungsten atoms in the W3S7 cluster core are bidentately coordinated by oxalate ligands and each oxalate ligand has two vacant coordination places available for bridging and making extended structures. The S2 ligands in the W3S7 4+ core participate in specific non-valence interactions and influence the packing to a large extent. The interplay of these two factors creates the interesting structural features presented below.

The S2 ligands in the W3S7 4+ core participate in specific non-valence interactions and influence the packing to a large extent. The interplay of these two factors creates the interesting structural features presented below.

elements.content: Materials and Methods. The starting potassium salt of [W3S7(C2O4)3]2- was prepared as described in the work. All the other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Methods. The starting potassium salt of [W3S7(C2O4)3]2- was prepared as described in the work. All the other reagents were purchased from commercial sources and used without further purification.

elements.content: Elemental analyses were carried out by the Novosibirsk Institute of Organic Chemistry microanalytical service. IR spectra (4000−400 cm-1) were recorded on a Scimitar FTS 2000 Fourier spectrometer. Thermogravimetric studies were done in an Ar atmosphere on a Netzsch TG 209 apparatus, at a rate of 10 °C min-1. A Quattro LC (quadrupole−hexapole−quadrupole) mass spectrometer with an orthogonal Z-spray-electrospray interface (Micromass, Manchester, U.K.) was used. The drying gas, as well as the nebulizing gas, was nitrogen at a flow rate of 400 and 80 L h-1, respectively. Sample solutions in methanol were infused via syringe pump directly to the interface at a flow rate of 6 μL min-1. A capillary voltage of 3.5 kV was used in the negative scan mode, and the cone voltage was varied between −10 to −60 V. The chemical composition of each peak was assigned by comparison of calculated and observed isotope patterns using the MassLynx 3.5 program. Magnetic susceptibility measurements on polycrystalline samples were carried out in the temperature range of 2−300 K with a Quantum Design SQUID magnetometer with an applied field of 500 Oe for T < 15 K and 5000 Oe for T > 15 K. Diamagnetic corrections of the constituent atoms were estimated from Pascal's constants.

elements.content: Synthesis of {[La(H 2 O) 6 ] 3 [W 3 S 7 (C 2 O 4 ) 3 ] 4 }Br·24.35H 2 O (Ia). A solution of K2[W3S7(C2O4)3]·0.5KBr·5H2O (50 mg, 0.04 mmol) in 10 mL of H2O was added to 8 mL of a 0.005 M solution of La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.04 mmol). The resultant solution became cloudy after few minutes and was kept in a closed vial at room temperature without filtration. The crystals of the product separated after 2 days. They were removed by decantation and washed with ethanol and ether, and dried in air for 2 days. Yield:  18 mg (32%). Anal. Calcd for C24H36BrLa3O66S28W12·16H2O:  C, 5.47; H, 1.30. Found:  C, 5.23; H, 1.09. IR (KBr, 4000−400 cm-1):  3420 s, 1703 s, 1671 s, 1432 w, 1388 m, 1318 vw, 1282 vw, 1246 vw, 913 vw, 800 w, 751 vw, 669 vw, 605 vw, 538 w, 469 vw. DTG:  20−150 °C, Δm = 9.5% (−28H2O).

elements.content: X-ray Structure Determinations. Crystals of Ia, Ib, IIa−IId, and III are orange slates or needles, and all but III are extremely unstable in air because of the loss of the water of crystallization. Crystallographic data and structure refinement details are given in Table . Diffraction data for all compounds were collected on a Bruker X8APEX CCD diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) using φ and ω scans of narrow (0.5°) frames. All structures were solved by direct methods and refined by full-matrix least-squares treatment against |F| 2 in anisotropic approximation using SHELX97 programs set. Since Ia was found to be isostructural with Ib and IIb−IId with IIa, the same model was used to refine all isostructural compounds. Absorption corrections were applied empirically using the SADABS program. The crystallographic data were deposited with the Cambridge Structural Database under deposition codes CCDC 605894−605899 for Ia, Ib, and IIa−IId, respectively, and CCDC 606764 for III. The site occupancy factors for disordered K+ and H2O were refined and then fixed in the calculated values. The atoms were refined in an isotropic approximation. Intermolecular contacts and packing motifs were analyzed according to refs and with the TOPOS 4.0 Professional program suit for crystallochemical analysis.

Synthesis and Spectroscopy. The triangular cluster complex, [W3S7(C2O4)3]2-, reacts with Ln3+ (Ln = La, Ce) in water in a molar ratio of 1:1 to form coordination polymers {[Ln(H2O)6]3[W3S7(C2O4)3]4}Br·xH2O (Ia and Ib). Under the same conditions, reactions with smaller Ln3+ (from Pr to Gd) ions result in the formation of nanosized discrete molecules [(W3S7(C2O4)3Ln(H2O)5)2(C2O4)], which crystallize as K[(W3S7(C2O4)3Ln(H2O)5)2(C2O4)]Br·xH2O (IIa−IId). Extra oxalate comes from partial fragmentation of the parent [W3S7(C2O4)3]2- under reaction conditions; this fact also explains the moderate yields of the complexes. The lanthanides in the Tb−Lu range gave only non-crystalline products, and heating the mixture did not improve the situation. Th4+ gives K2[(W3S7(C2O4)3)4Th2(OH)2(H2O)10]·14.33H2O (III) with a nanosized discrete anion (with the separation of about 2.7 nm between the most distant parts of the molecule), in which two thorium atoms are bridged by two hydroxides into the Th2(OH)2 6+ unit, and each Th is further coordinated by five water molecules and two monodentate [W3S7(C2O4)]2- cluster ligands. These results demonstrate that [W3S7(C2O4)3]2- functions as an effective building block for the construction of the oxalato-bridged heteropolynuclear structures incorporating rare-earth and actinide ions. The partial fragmentation of a parent oxalato complex with the formation of the Ln2(μ-C2O4) was observed before in the reactions of [Cr(bpy)(C2O4)2]- with Ln3+ (Ln = La, Pr, Gd). Our attempts to coordinate Er3+ or Pr3+ to [Nb2(S2)2(C2O4)4]4- gave only the corresponding Ln oxalates Ln2(C2O4)3·xH2O. Similarly, [Cr(C2O4)3]3- is destroyed (in water). It is known that Th(IV) undergoes extensive hydrolysis in aqueous solutions. Polymerization of monomeric hydrolyzed Th(IV) species proceeds usually thorough μ-OH bridges.

Results and Discussion

 Synthesis and Spectroscopy. The triangular cluster complex, [W3S7(C2O4)3]2-, reacts with Ln3+ (Ln = La, Ce) in water in a molar ratio of 1:1 to form coordination polymers {[Ln(H2O)6]3[W3S7(C2O4)3]4}Br⋅xH2O (Ia and Ib). Under the same conditions, reactions with smaller Ln3+ (from Pr to Gd) ions result in the formation of nanosized discrete molecules [(W3S7(C2O4)3Ln(H2O)5)2(C2O4)], which crystallize as K[(W3S7(C2O4)3Ln(H2O)5)2(C2O4)]Br⋅xH2O (IIa-IId). Extra oxalate comes from partial fragmentation of the parent [W3S7(C2O4)3]2- under reaction conditions; this fact also explains the moderate yields of the complexes. The lanthanides in the Tb-Lu range gave only non-crystalline products, and heating the mixture did not improve the situation. Th4+ gives K2[(W3S7(C2O4)3)4Th2(OH)2(H2O)10]⋅14.33H2O (III) with a nanosized discrete anion (with the separation of about 2.7 nm between the most distant parts of the molecule), in which two thorium atoms are bridged by two hydroxides into the Th2(OH)2 6+ unit, and each Th is further coordinated by five water molecules and two monodentate [W3S7(C2O4)]2- cluster ligands. These results demonstrate that [W3S7(C2O4)3]2- functions as an effective building block for the construction of the oxalato-bridged heteropolynuclear structures incorporating rare-earth and actinide ions. The partial fragmentation of a parent oxalato complex with the formation of the Ln2(μ-C2O4) was observed before in the reactions of [Cr(bpy)(C2O4)2]- with Ln3+ (Ln = La, Pr, Gd). Our attempts to coordinate Er3+ or Pr3+ to [Nb2(S2)2(C2O4)4]4- gave only the corresponding Ln oxalates Ln2(C2O4)3⋅xH2O. Similarly, [Cr(C2O4)3]3- is destroyed (in water). It is known that Th(IV) undergoes extensive hydrolysis in aqueous solutions. Polymerization of monomeric hydrolyzed Th(IV) species proceeds usually thorough μ-OH bridges.

elements.content: Magnetic susceptibility measurements in the temperature range of 2−300 K show antiferromagnetic interactions between two lanthanide ions (d(Ln−Ln) = 6.5−6.8 Å) for IIa, IIb, and IId. The ground state for a Gd(III) ion is 8S7/2 and it is located at some 104 cm-1 below the first excited-state and is not perturbed by ligand field effects. For such a species, the TIP is expected to be negligible, and the Zeeman factor g J is expected to be 2.0. Thus, Gd(III) mononuclear species are expected to follow the Curie law with a χM T value of 7.88 cm3 mol-1 K.The magnetic properties of IId under the form of the χM T product versus T [χM being the magnetic susceptibility per two Gd(III) cations] are shown in Figure S1. The value of χ M T at room temperature is 15.81 cm3 mol-1 K, and this value remains almost constant up to 25 K and decreases at lower temperatures, reaching a value of 10.73 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. Because IId can be seen as a Gd(III) dinuclear entity, the magnetic behavior of Gd is the expected for a weakly antiferromagnetically coupled dinuclear compound. The magnetic properties of IId have been analyzed by means of a simple dimer law deduced from the isotropic spin Hamiltonian H = − jS Gd(1) S Gd(1a) . The best fit parameters are j = −0.080(1) cm-1, g = 2.00(1), and R = 5.1 × 10-5. The magnetization curve follows the Brillouin function for two isolated Gd(III) ions with g = 2.0 and S = 7. The antiferromagnetic coupling is the result of the coupling of orbitals of same symmetry, and the low value of the coupling constant is one of the features of the 4f trivalent cations, for which the singly occupied orbitals are very efficiently shielded by the fully occupied 5s and the 5p orbitals and have very little interaction with the orbitals of the bridging ligands.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of IIb are shown in Figure S2. The value of χM T at room temperature is 2.95 cm3 mol-1 K, slightly lower than the expected for the 4I9/2 ground state and monotonically decrease as T is lowered to reach a value of 1.15 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. This behavior is mainly related to the thermal depopulation of the ligand field energy levels of the multiplet.

elements.content: A χM T value of 3.2 cm3 mol-1 K is expected for IIa in which we have two Pr(III) ions in a 3H4 ground state (1.60 cm3 mol-1 K per Pr(III) ion). Thus the value of 3.1 cm3 mol-1 K obtained is as expected (Figure S3). Here again the decrease of the χM T values upon cooling must be caused by the depopulation of the energy levels splitted by the ligand field effect.

elements.content: The magnetic properties of IId are not affected by the excited states nor by the ligand field effects. For this compound, it has been possible to obtain the coupling constant, which lies in the range of previous studies. However, the magnetic behavior of IIb and IIa are more complicated. The χM T values obtained experimentally are very close to those expected for the respective ground states, but they do not follow the Curie law upon lowering of the temperature. This behavior could be the result of the occurrence antiferromagnetic coupling or to the thermal depopulation of the energy levels of the multiplet splitted by the ligand field. We think that this latter factor is the most important in the decay of the χM T values upon cooling.

elements.content: Thermogravimetric study of {[La(H2O)6]3[W3S7(C2O4)3]4}Br·24.35H2O (Ia), {[Ce(H2O)6]3[W3S7(C2O4)3]4}Br·24.95H2O (Ib), and K[(W3S7(C2O4)3Nd(H2O)5)2(C2O4)]Br·14H2O (IIb) shows that after complete removal both of the water of crystallization and the water molecules coordinated to the lanthanide below 150−170 °C, decomposition of the oxalate ligands starts only at 250 °C. Attempts to remove the water of crystallization from Ib by heating at 100 °C (in vacuo) cause a loss of crystallinity.

Attempts to remove the water of crystallization from Ib by heating at 100 °C (in vacuo) cause a loss of crystallinity.

elements.content: The IR spectra of Ia, Ib, IIa−IId, and III are similar, and each displays two strong bands at 1701−1704 (narrow) and 1648−1671 cm-1 (broad), attributable to the νas(COO-) and two bands at 1428−1442 and 1373−1392 cm-1 for νs(COO-). Deconvolution of the broad bands with maxima at 1648 cm-1 for IIa, 1660 cm-1 for IIb, and 1668 cm-1 for IIc gives two new bands centered at 1676 and 1636 cm-1 for IIa, 1675 and 1635 cm-1 for IIb, and 1678 and 1637 cm-1 for IIc. The appearance of several bands both for νas and νs is indicative of the presence of a different environment around the oxalate ligands. In the spectra of K2[W3S7(C2O4)3]·0.5KBr·4H2O, terminal oxalates appear at 1677 cm-1. On the other side, in Ln2(C2O4)3·xH2O, where all oxalates are μ2-bridging, νas(COO-) appears at 1620−1640 cm-1. Thus, tentatively, in IIa−IIc, the bands at 1635−1637 cm-1 correspond to the Ln2(μ-C2O4) unit, those at 1675−1678 cm-1 correspond to the terminal oxalates, and those at 1701−1704 cm-1 correspond to the W(μ-C2O4)Ln bridges. The decrease of vibration frequency from W to Ln correlates very well with expected decrease in covalence of the M−O bonds.

elements.content: Structure Description. The complexes with Ln3+, obtained in this work, can be divided into two structural types designated as types I and II. Type I includes coordination polymers {[Ln(H2O)6]3[W3S7(C2O4)3]4}Br·xH2O, x = 24.3(8) and 25.0(8) for Ln = La (Ia) and Ce (Ib), respectively. Smaller Ln3+ cations, Ln = Pr (IIa), Nd (IIb), Sm (IIc), and Gd (IId) give K[(W3S7(C2O4)3Ln(H2O)5)2(C2O4)]Br·xH2O, x = 13(1)−15(1) with a discrete, non-polymeric structure (Type II). The Eu complex also belongs to this type according to the cell parameter measurements. Type III is represented only by K2[(W3S7(C2O4)3)4Th2(OH)2(H2O)10]·14.33H2O. Main bond distance ranges for all complexes are given in Table .

The La and Ce compounds crystallize in a trigonal crystal system. The structure contains two independent cluster anions [W3S7(ox)3]2-, one of them is in a general position (Figure a), and the other is on a 3-fold axis (Figure b). This rather complex structure is in fact built of distinct subunits, designated A, B, and C. The subunit A contains alternating cluster anions linked to the cationic moieties Ln(H2O)6 3+ (CN(Ln) = 10, Figure , subunit A). This linking produces cationic honeycomb layers {[Ln(H2O)6]3[W3S7(C2O4)3]2} n 5 n + (Figure a). The layers involve only 1/3 of the total number of the cluster anions. The remaining 2/3 form subunit B, which contains Ln(H2O)6 3+ units, coordinated to two cluster anions through three oxygen atoms of two terminal oxalates. The Ln atom is disordered over two positions related by a 2-fold axis (space group P32, CN(Ln) = 9) (Figure , subunit B). In addition, each cluster anion from A, together with three cluster anions from B, shares a Br- anion via short contacts Sax···Br- (3.38−3.48 Å), to give sandwichlike associates (Figure , subunit C). The Br- anion seems to be more strongly attracted to the A subunits as follows from the lengths of the corresponding contacts:  Sax(A)···Br- = 3.36−3.41 Å, 3Sax(B)···Br- = 3.47−3.48 Å for both Ia and Ib (Figure ). It is worth stressing that, although the Sax−X- contacts are quite common in the structures of M3S7 clusters, in most cases they lead to the “true” sandwiches of the type {(M3Q7)2X} (M = Mo, W; Q = S, Se, Te). Although examples of the {W3S7}4+ clusters are rather scarce in general, {(W3S7)2Br} “sandwiches” were observed in K2.5[W3S7(ox)3]Br0.5·5H2O. The axial contacts Sax···Br in that case are shorter, 3.100−3.302 Å. The only example of the association of four cluster units around a halide so far known was furnished by [Mo3S7{(EtO)2PS2}3]4I(HgI3)3·4H2O where {(Mo3S7)4I} associates were observed. Remarkably, the Sax···Γ contacts in the latter are much shorter than in Ia and Ib, despite I- being 0.15 Å larger than Br-. In addition, unlike in I, all 12, Sax···Γ contacts are related by symmetry and have identical lengths of 3.059 Å. A comparison of the Sax···Br- contacts in I and K2.5[W3S7(ox)3]Br0.5·5H2O shows that spatial requirements alone are unlikely to cause such a significant lengthening of the contacts in I.

elements.content: As a whole, structure type I can be described as covalent layers, decorated by turns below and above each layer with the sandwich associates (Figure ). This structure presents the first example of the involvement of a Sax−X- contact into a polymeric framework. It also features channels which are approximately trigonal in cross-section of about d min ≈ 9.3 Å in diameter, filled with severely disordered water molecules, in accordance with the hydration number of ∼25 H2O per formula unit.

elements.content: Type II structures consists of neutral molecules [(W3S7(ox)3Ln(H2O)5)2(ox)], Ln = Pr, Nd, Sm, and Gd (CN (Ln) = 9, Figure ). Note that apart from these structures, the only molecular structure with the Ln2(μ-C2O4) unit is found in hexanuclear [Ln2(μ-ox){Cr(bpy)(μ-ox)(ox)}4(H2O)6], Ln = La, Pr. In II, the molecules are linked into infinite zigzag anionic chains through axial contacts 3Sax···Br- where d(Sax···Br-) = 3.02−3.26 Å. These bromides are located in the fracture points of the chains (Figure ). The chains are arranged in a hexagonal motif. The shortening of the Ln−O bonds in the series leads to a regular change in the chain geometry. To describe the latter quantitavely, we introduce stretching parameter α and torsion parameter β (Figure S4). When the Ln−O distances shorten, the cell volume decreases as a whole, but not strictly linearly (Figure S5). The neutral complex molecules that constitute the chain links thus shorten, and the chains straighten, which can be followed by increase in the torsion angle β. The evolution of stretching parameter α is not so straightforward, indicating that factors other than the Ln−O bond shortening are also operative (Figure S6).

elements.content: Notwithstanding directed non-valence Sax···Br- interactions and expressly nonspherical complex molecules, the packing of these relatively large units [(W3S7(C2O4)3Ln(H2O)5)2(C2O4)], though very complex, is topologically equivalent to face-centered cubic packing. The K+ cations and solvent water molecules fill the voids. Interestingly, the α parameter correlates well with the degree of the deviation from the idealized fcc packing. The more a chain is folded, the more distorted the packing becomes (Figure S6).

elements.content: Compound III contains complex anions [(W3S7(C2O4)3)4-Th2(OH)2(H2O)10]2- (Figure ), built around the {Th2(OH)2}6+ dimeric unit, which occupies the inversion center. Each Th atom monodentately coordinates two [W3S7(ox)3]2- ions via oxalate oxygens. The remaining five coordinating sites at Th are occupied with water molecules, CN(Th) = 9. The distances in {Th2(OH)2}6+ are in good agreement with other Th bishydroxo complexes (Table ). The main bond lengths in III are given in Table . Unlike I and II, this structure does not contain halides. Instead, the anions [(W3S7(C2O4)3)4Th2(OH)2(H2O)10]2- form dimeric associates between themselves in such a way that the cluster anions [W3S7(ox)3]2- are mutually bound via six Sax···O contacts (Figure a) (Sax···O = 2.927(9)−3.153(9)Å) (Table ). In this way, each anion [(W3S7(C2O4)3)4Th2(OH)2(H2O)10]2- interacts with four other anions, giving rise to layers (Figure b). Between the layers, K+ and disordered solvent water molecules are located. The layers are stacked to allow the center of gravity of [(W3S7(C2O4)3)4Th2(OH)2(H2O)10]2- to build a slightly distorted fcc motif.

elements.content: Thus, coordination of [W3S7(ox)3]2- to Ln3+ or Th4+ produces, depending on the cation, either discrete molecular complexes (I and III) or a layered structure (II). The latter type of structure is found in the rare-earth oxalates Ln2(C2O4)3·xH2O (x = 6−10; Ln = Sc, Y, La−Lu). In that case, the net is built of fused hexagonal Ln6(μ-C2O4)6 rings, and guest molecules other then water (like N2H4) can enter the channels or interlayer space. The crystal structure of Gd2(ox)[Cu(pba)]3[Cu(H2O)5]·20H2O (pba = 1,3-propylenebis(oxamato))30 consists of puckered ladderlike strands of Gd[Cu(pba)] units connected into a two-dimensional honeycomb pattern by oxalato groups between two Gd3+ ions. Again, distorted hexagonal rings result. Additionally, [Cu(H2O)5]2+ ions are found between the layers. This shows that layered oxalato-bridged coordination polymers have the potential to accommodate various guests. In the structure of (H3O)[Yb(ox)Ni(S2C2O2)2·1.5H2O, there are cyclic tetramers (YbO2C2O2)4, not hexamers, linking together at Yb into infinite chains by [Ni(S2C2O2)2]2-.

elements.content: This work shows that oxalate cluster complex [W3S7(ox)3]2- can function as building block for coordination polymers. In fact it participates in building of the polymeric framework in two ways:  by direct coordination of a heterometal through oxalate oxygens (serving as node a three-connected net) and by (axial) contacts, which, in turn, link together the cluster fragments. These structures display attractive possibilities of using non-valence interactions 3Sax···Hal- and 3Sax···O(C2O4 2-) to diversify crystal packing because they play a significant role in intermolecular interactions.

These structures display attractive possibilities of using non-valence interactions 3Sax⋅⋅⋅Hal- and 3Sax⋅⋅⋅O(C2O4 2-) to diversify crystal packing because they play a significant role in intermolecular interactions.

Synthesis of {[La(H 2 O) 6 ] 3 [W 3 S 7 (C 2 O 4 ) 3 ] 4 }Br·24.35H 2 O (Ia). A solution of K2[W3S7(C2O4)3]·0.5KBr·5H2O (50 mg, 0.04 mmol) in 10 mL of H2O was added to 8 mL of a 0.005 M solution of La(NO3)3·6H2O (0.04 mmol). The resultant solution became cloudy after few minutes and was kept in a closed vial at room temperature without filtration. The crystals of the product separated after 2 days. They were removed by decantation and washed with ethanol and ether, and dried in air for 2 days. Yield:  18 mg (32%). Anal. Calcd for C24H36BrLa3O66S28W12·16H2O:  C, 5.47; H, 1.30. Found:  C, 5.23; H, 1.09. IR (KBr, 4000−400 cm-1):  3420 s, 1703 s, 1671 s, 1432 w, 1388 m, 1318 vw, 1282 vw, 1246 vw, 913 vw, 800 w, 751 vw, 669 vw, 605 vw, 538 w, 469 vw. DTG:  20−150 °C, Δm = 9.5% (−28H2O).

Synthesis of {[Ce(H 2 O) 6 ] 3 [W 3 S 7 (C 2 O 4 ) 3 ] 4 }Br·24.95H 2 O (Ib). The synthesis is the same as that described above. A solution of K2[W3S7(C2O4)3]·0.5KBr·5H2O (50 mg, 0.04 mmol) in 10 mL of H2O was added to 8 mL of a 0.005 M solution of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O (0.04 mmol). Yield:  23 mg (41%). Anal. Calcd for C24H36BrCe3O66S28W12·10H2O:  C, 5.58; H, 1.09. Found:  C, 5.70; H, 0.96. IR (KBr, 4000−400 cm-1):  3438 s, 1702 s, 1662 s, 1437 vw, 1387 m, 1284 vw, 913 vw, 801 w, 602 vw, 539 w, 464 vw. DTG:  20−150 °C, Δm = 10.5% (−31H2O).

cln_elements.content:
The magnetic properties of IIb are shown in Figure S2. The value of χM T at room temperature is 2.95 cm3 mol-1 K, slightly lower than the expected for the 4I9/2 ground state and monotonically decrease as T is lowered to reach a value of 1.15 cm3 mol-1 K at 2 K. This behavior is mainly related to the thermal depopulation of the ligand field energy levels of the multiplet.

A χM T value of 3.2 cm3 mol-1 K is expected for IIa in which we have two Pr(III) ions in a 3H4 ground state (1.60 cm3 mol-1 K per Pr(III) ion). Thus the value of 3.1 cm3 mol-1 K obtained is as expected (Figure S3). Here again the decrease of the χM T values upon cooling must be caused by the depopulation of the energy levels splitted by the ligand field effect.
